Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Deciphering Brown Dwarf Spectra: Disentangling Temperature, Age, Metallicity, Cloud Signatures
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative proposal brings together the theoretical and observational skills from two researchers to conduct a study of L-dwarfs, which are relatively cool brown dwarf stellar objects. They will use optical and infrared spectroscopy and photometry of approximately thirty L- dwarfs to constrain and revise models of the atmospheres and evolution of low mass stellar objects. They will use archive data from Spitzer IRAC and 2MASS surveys, and new data from a 1.3-m telescope in Chile and 2.4-m MDM telescope. They will focus on determining accurate values of effective temperature, mass and metallicity of the dwarfs, and to better understand why many young brown dwarfs are not as luminous as models predict.

Broader impacts include the research training of undergraduate students from underrepresented groups from the City University of New York system, supporting the AstroBetter blog, producing planetarium videos and other public outreach activities through the American Museum of Natural History.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We established a new way to analyze the kinematics of brown dwarfs in order to confirm their membership in young moving groups. This method is published in Riedel, A. R., Blunt, S. C., Lambrides, E. L., Rice, E. L., Cruz, K. L., & Faherty, J. K. (2017), The Astronomical Journal, 153, 95.

As a result of our kinematic analysis, over half of our candidate young brown dwarfs have been confirmed as members of young moving groups with well constrained ages. Intriguingly, many of the suspected young objects are not confirmed in any moving group. Further, preliminary analysis of low?resolution data does not identify any spectral features that are strongly age?sensitive. These results were published in Faherty, J. K., Riedel, A. R., Cruz, K. L., Gagne, J., Filippazzo, J. C., Lambrides, E., Fica, H., Weinberger, A., Thorstensen, J. R., Tinney, C. G., Baldassare, V., Lemonier, E., & Rice, E. L. (2016), The Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series, 225, 10.

We devised a new way to analyze the near infrared spectra of L dwarfs which anchors the classification more tightly to temperature. This is published in Cruz, K. L., N??ez, A., Burgasser, A. J., Abrahams, E., Rice, E. L., Reid, I. N., & Looper, D. (2018), The Astronomical Journal, 155, 34.

We studied the effect of small dust grains in the atmospheres of young brown dwarfs has revealed that the grain size distribution might have a temperature dependence with the cooler brown dwarfs have a wider distribution of grain sizes than the hotter ones. These results are published in Hiranaka, K., Cruz, K. L., Douglas, S. T., Marley, M. S., & Baldassare, V. F. (2016), The Astrophysical Journal, 830, 96.

We added >1000 objects to the the BDNYC database (http://database.bdnyc.org). This database is a compilation of information on low mass stars, brown dwarfs, and low mass companions available for public use.

We mentored numerous students (mostly women) and launched them into PhD programs (Harvard, Berkeley, NYU, JHU, Caltech) and postdoctoral fellowships (Caltech) and staff positions (STScI).
